comments.body: I think this is something that @a14n recently fixed.  Plan is to get a plugin availalbe to the analyzer to check this.  But for now I suspect we shouldn't re-introduce the extra space.
It's not broken, actually.  That's how dartfmt formats it, and Ian has explicitly said that the extra spaces are fine.
Ahh I see - sorry, this isn't one of the cases that his changes impacted.  sorry about that

See https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/25251#pullrequestreview-184323664

I'm not aware of the final decision about that and I'm interested because at some point I will add a rule to check this style.
I don't think it counts as a "final decision", but Ian expressed "not having a strong opinion about this" a while ago: https://github.com/dart-lang/dart_style/issues/658#issuecomment-371346116

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +199,203 @@    this.platform = const LocalPlatform(),
    HttpReader httpReader,
  })  : assert(revision.length == 40),
        flutterRoot = Directory(path.join(tempDir.path, 'flutter')),
        httpReader = httpReader ?? http.readBytes,

comments.body:
Please add a comment pointing to docs for the attrib command.

Separately, is there anything that could cause the attrib command not to be present?

Added link.

It ships with Windows. The only reason it wouldn't be available is if you've hosed your Windows setup.

Rather than excluding by git, could we just exclude everything from the `dev/` folder specifically?

That way, if we move to distributing the gallery some other way (e.g. by pub somehow?) this won't break.
I floated that idea and the concern was that it could break the offline workflow. Lacking good integration tests this is a minimal fix to reduce the size
Are there any other binaries that we should check? e.g. `pub`?

i'll add a TODO, my plans are to migrate this script into `//flutter/dev/tools`, then it can hook into [this logic](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/dev/tools/lib/codesign.dart) to test every binary that is executable.

I tried to have this script call that one, but it was tricky, and this script is difficult to test--I was worried it would work locally but fail on LUCI when I'm actually trying to publish.
That's a valid concern: this type of this is always hard to test without actually publishing. A TODO is fine.

Man, JSON really is awkward without dynamic, isn't it?

Would this (and other similar cases) be easier to read if the cast value was broken out into it's own local var?

Maybe sometimes?  I tried doing that in some places, but it sometimes just gets in the way by adding more noise.

JSON (and YAML) really suck to use when you have strict typing: they just don't _do_ strict typing.
